form.definition: noun I or i is the ninth letter of the English alphabet.
pronoun You use I when you are talking about yourself. I like Australia. Anna and I go to TAFE together.
noun Ice is frozen water. The winter was so cold that the water in the dam turned to ice. Would you like ice in your drink?
verb If you ice a cake, you spread icing over it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective icy The roads were icy and dangerous.

form.definition: noun An iceberg is a huge mass of ice which floats in the sea.
noun Ice-cream is a frozen dessert made from cream or milk. I bought a litre tub of ice-cream.
noun An ice-cream is a scoop of this food served in a cone. The kids were clamouring for ice-creams.
noun An icicle is a long, thin piece of ice which forms when water freezes as it runs down a wall or drips from a surface.
noun Icing is a sweet paste used for decorating cakes and biscuits. It is made from very fine sugar mixed with water or butter, and often with colouring and flavouring added.
abbreviation for identification. Do you have any ID with you?

noun An idea is a thought or a picture that you have in your mind. My ideas about Australia were quite different from the reality. There were so many ideas running through my mind that I couldn't sleep. Can you give me some idea when you'll arrive?
noun An idea is a plan or scheme for doing something. It was Clem's idea to go to the movies. I've got an idea! Why don't we ask Greg to help? Whatever gave you the idea of painting it black?
noun An idea is also a belief or opinion about something. He has some strange ideas about bringing up children. Her experience abroad changed her ideas. I had an idea that he'd know all about it.

have no idea If you say you have no idea when someone asks you a question, you mean that you don't know anything about it. 'How much did Mary's dress cost?' 'I've no idea.' I've no idea when he'll be back, I'm afraid. Are you telling me you've no idea how the money came to be in your pocket?

adjective If something is ideal, it is as good as it possibly can be. The pavilion at the beach would be an ideal place for a party. The ideal solution would be for Janet to withdraw voluntarily. It's not ideal, but it'll have to do.

noun An ideal is something that is the best of its type that you can possibly imagine. A brown and white stripe would be the ideal, but plain brown is OK. She's a great teacherwe all look up to her as our ideal.

noun An ideal is a principle that you firmly believe in, even though it may not be easy to achieve. We all share the ideal of a just and harmonious society. As he grew older, he became cynical about the ideals of his youth.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun idealism noun idealist adjective idealistic

form.definition: adjective If two things are identical, they are exactly the same as each other. The two pictures are almost identical, but there are five differencescan you spot them? Dawn and Eve are identical twins. Isn't this identical to his earlier proposal?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See identity.adverb identically

form.definition: noun If someone asks you for some identification, they want you to show them something which proves who you are, such as your driver's licence or passport. Have you got any identification on you?
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is identity.

form.definition: verb If you identify someone or something, you recognise them and can name them or point them out. Can you identify this tune? She identified one of the men in the photo as the rapist. The corpse has still not been identified. I can't quite identify that smell.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See identification.

form.definition: noun Your identity is who you are. You may have to prove your identity before they'll give you the money. The police are anxious to establish the identity of a man seen walking his dog near the murder site.
noun Identity is another word for identification.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See identification.

form.definition: noun An idiom is a group of words whose meaning you can't work out by knowing the words on their own. For example, if you say 'Jane drives me up the wall', you are using an idiom which means that Jane irritates you.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective idiomatic

form.definition: noun You describe someone as an idiot if you think they have done or said something very stupid. What an idiot Ty isfancy balancing the paint can there! You idiot, of course I love you! I'm an idiotwhy on earth didn't I realise before? They're a bunch of idiots.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective idiotic She's got some idiotic idea about us all going in one car.

form.definition: adjective If someone is idle, they are lazy. They're an idle bunch of bludgers.
adjective If you are idle, you are not doing anything. She hates being idle.
adjective If machines are idle, they are not being used. The machines were idle for four days during the strike.
verb If a car engine is idling, it is turning over at its lowest speed and the car is generally not moving.

idle away If you idle away your time, you spend your time doing nothing important. I've got a couple of hours to idle away before the flight. Tariq idled away the first semester and now he's panicking about getting through the course.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun idleness

form.definition: noun An idol is a statue or image which people worship as a god.

An idol is also a person that someone loves or admires a lot, usually without knowing them very well. Samira's always going to see the latest bandsshe has a different idol every week. When I was growing up, my uncle was an idol to me. ... WORD FAMILYverb idolise (<or> idolize) Betty idolises Elvis Presley.

abbreviation for the Latin id est, which means 'that is'. You use this in writing to give a fuller explanation of something. Applications must be received by the end of next month, i.e. 31 July. Reports were presented by each member of the committee, i.e. Marla, John and Bruce.
conjunction You use if to express a condition that must be true before something else can happen. You'll get there in time, if you leave now.
conjunction You use if to mean 'whether' in questions where the answer must be 'yes' or 'no'. He wants to know if we're going.
conjunction You use if to introduce a statement about something that might have happened in the past although you know it didn't. If we'd seen him coming, we'd have hidden round the corner.

verb If something ignites, it catches fire. There was a tremendous explosion when the gas ignited. The twigs were too damp to ignite. Our best-selling barbecue has a button to ignite the gas automatically.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See ignition.

form.definition: noun The ignition in a car is the device which starts the engine. It sets off the sparks which ignite the fuel gases in the cylinders. I left the keys in the ignition.
noun Ignition is something igniting or catching fire.

adjective If someone is ignorant, they are uneducated or know very little about a particular subject. Navin is so ignoranthe doesn't even know the name of our Prime Minister. When it comes to dressmaking, I'm totally ignorant. Why should I have to answer to that ignorant slob?
adjective If you are ignorant of something, you do not know about it. The owner, ignorant of the true value of the clock, sold it for next to nothing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun ignorance There is no excuse for that sort of ignorance.

form.definition: verb If you ignore someone or something, you do not take any notice of them. You do not let them disrupt you in what you are doing. The minister ignored the demonstrators and carried on speaking. I said good morning, but he ignored me and walked straight past. Never ignore any changes in a mole.
adjective If you are ill, you are sick. I was ill today so I didn't go to work. Sharon is seriously ill. You look really ill.
adjective Ill also means 'bad' or 'harmful'. It is used in this meaning only with a few nouns. The delay had no ill effect on the project. He suffers from ill health.

adverb Ill also means 'badly' or 'with difficulty'. It is used in this meaning only with certain words. You would be ill advised to ignore him. The suggestion was ill timed. It will cost money that I can ill afford.
noun In old-fashioned language, ill is evil or harm. He promised to do me no ill.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun illness She died after a long illness.

form.definition: adjective If something is illegal, anyone who does it is breaking the law. It is illegal to drive a car without a licence.
adjective An illegal immigrant is someone who comes to a country and stays without official permission.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb illegally His car was parked there illegally.

form.definition: adjective If something is illegible, you cannot read it. It is impossible to make out what the words are. Simon's handwriting is illegible. The note was illegible after it had been through the wash in the pocket of my jeans.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with eligible.

form.definition: adjective An illegitimate child is born to parents who are not married to each other. The official term for this in Australian law is ex-nuptial.
adjective If something is illegitimate, it is not right or proper. He was involved in illegitimate business deals. It would be illegitimate to automatically assume that she was involved.

adjective If something is illicit, it is not morally right or not approved of by society. Tina is having an illicit love affair with her brother-in-law. He was suspected of making illicit gains on the deals.
adjective If someone is illiterate, they do not know how to read and write in a particular language.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is literate. ... WORD FAMILYnoun illiteracy

form.definition: verb If you illuminate something, you shine light on it and make it easier to see. The fountains in the park are illuminated at night.

verb If you illuminate something, you make it clearer and easier to understand. She gave several examples to illuminate her point. The pattern of early settlement in Australia has been illuminated by some recently discovered documents.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective illuminating What she said was very illuminating.noun illumination

form.definition: noun An illusion is something that you think you see but which isn't really there or doesn't really happen. The magician seemed to be pulling the rabbits out of his hat, but it was only an illusion.
noun An illusion is an idea or belief you have which is not true. I thought that once we were married he'd stop drinking, but it was just an illusion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective illusory The advantages of the plan are largely illusory.

form.definition: verb If you illustrate a story or a book, you provide pictures to go with the writing and add to it. Ralph wrote wonderful letters to the girls and illustrated them beautifully. The textbook is fully illustrated with over 200 line drawings and 32 pages of coloured plates.

verb If you illustrate something that you are saying, you give examples to make it clear. You should illustrate each point you make with a reference to the text. These failures illustrate how badly thought out the scheme was in the first place.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun illustration The illustrations are beautiful. This is an illustration of my point.noun illustrator Children's books rely on a partnership between the author and the illustrator.

form.definition: noun An image is the picture that you see in something such as a mirror, camera lens or TV screen. She stared at her image in the water. In one corner of the photo there was a ghostly image.
noun An image is a picture in your mind. She doesn't fit the image I had of her at all. My head was filled with strange thoughts and images.

noun Someone's image is the way that they appear to other people. The company is trying to improve its image with the people. She projects a cheerful image, but really she's very insecure. I decided it was time to change my image, so I dyed my hair.
If you are the image of someone else, you look exactly like them. Eleanor's the image of her grandmother at the same age.
adjective If something is imaginary, it does not really exist, but has been invented in someone's mind. Many small children have imaginary friends.

noun Your imagination is the ability you have to invent interesting or exciting things in your mind. Her stories show great imagination. I can see it all in my imagination. The project needs someone with vision and imagination.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective imaginative She's an imaginative child. We need an imaginative general manager.

form.definition: verb If you imagine something, your mind forms a picture or idea about it. Try to imagine that you're at the beach. I can't imagine how that got there!
verb If you imagine something, you believe that you are aware of it, but it isn't real. I must have imagined that conversation. Am I imagining it, or is it hot in here?
verb If you imagine that something is the case, you think or assume it's so. I imagine he'll be very pleased to see you all. We'll start at two as usual, I imagine.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See imaginary.noun See imagination.

form.definition: noun An imam is the priest of a mosque where followers of Islam worship.
noun An imbecile is someone who is completely stupid. What an imbecile Angelo is!

verb If you imitate someone, you copy the way they speak or behave, often as a way of making fun of them. The whole class laughs when Bob imitates the teacher. The teacher pronounces the words for the class to imitate.
verb If you imitate someone, you use them as a model because you want to be like them. He's taken up smoking purely because he wants to imitate his mates.

verb If you imitate something, you make something that's as much like it as possible. Chemists can now imitate most of these flavours in the laboratory. Her paintings imitate the style of medieval art. ... WORD FAMILYnoun imitation Bob's very good at imitations.adjective imitation It's a gas fire with imitation lumps of coal.
adjective If something is immaculate, it is perfectly clean and tidy. The tenants left the house immaculate.
adjective If something is immaculate, it is perfect. Taryn's assignment was immaculateI couldn't find any fault with it.
adjective If something is immature, it has not yet developed fully. ...immature plants.
adjective Someone who is immature does not behave in a sensible way or they are less mature than you would expect.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun immaturity

form.definition: adjective An immediate event happens straight away. He called for an immediate inquiry into the matter. The leadership challenge was an immediate consequence of the party's poor showing at the polls.

adjective Something that is immediate exists now and needs prompt attention. We should deal first of all with our immediate problems. What additional resources do you need in the immediate future? There is no immediate danger.

adjective Your immediate family is your very close family. Usually this is limited to your parents, brothers and sisters, and children. In my immediate family I have my mother and father and two sisters. The hospital is allowing visits only by immediate family members.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb immediately I demand to see him immediately. I immediately realised my mistake.

form.definition: adjective If something is immense, it is extremely large. Gerry has an immense appetite. We've already wasted an immense amount of time. They live in an immense house in the country. She earns an immense salary.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb immensely It's all immensely depressing. I was immensely bored.

form.definition: verb If you immerse something, you place it in a liquid so that the liquid covers it completely. Ensure that the garment is thoroughly immersed in the dye. The boat capsized and we were immersed in the sea.

immerse yourself If you immerse yourself in something, you become totally involved in it. He's so immersed in his work, he hardly has time for the family. The best way to become fluent is to go to a country where the language is spoken and immerse yourself.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun immersion

dictionary.entry: immigrant`Im@gr@nt noun An immigrant is someone who comes to live in a new country. After World War II, many immigrants from Central and Southern Europe came to live in Australia. ... COMPAREthis with emigrant. ... WORD FAMILYverb immigrate noun immigration

form.definition: adjective If something is imminent, it is likely to happen soon or at any moment. His visit is imminenthe may even arrive before you leave. We are facing imminent disaster.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis word with eminent.

form.definition: adjective If something is immoral, it is morally wrong. Some people think evading income tax is immoral, others think it's fine if you can get away with it.
adjective If someone or something is immortal, they never die. They live for ever. These trees are practically immortalthey live several hundred years.
adjective If someone or something is immortal, they are so outstanding or famous that they will be remembered for years to come. He urged us to read the works of the immortal Patrick White.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun immortality

dictionary.entry: immuneI`mju:n adjective If you are immune to something, it doesn't affect or harm you. I've had measles so I'm immune to it now. She was totally immune to criticism and carried on exactly as before. ... WORD FAMILYadjective immune The body's immune system protects us from disease.noun immunisation (<or> immunization) Has Rada had all her immunisations?verb immunise (or immunize) All children should be immunised against polio.noun immunity He built up an immunity to the disease. She sought immunity from prosecution.

form.definition: noun The impact is the force with which one thing strikes another. The two cars collided with such an impact that I was thrown out onto the road. The wall buckled under the impact.

noun The impact of something on another thing is the effect it has on it. The floods will have a serious impact on the economic situation in the town. At first I didn't feel the full impact of his death.
verb If you impair something, you damage it so that it cannot work properly. The impurities impair the action of the chemical. Walid's vision is impaired, so he has to wear strong glasses.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun impairment

dictionary.entry: impartialIm`pa:S@l adjective If you are impartial, you are not in favour of either side in a dispute. We need an impartial observer to decide the issue. You can't expect her to be impartialshe had a big quarrel with Stavros years ago. ... WORD FAMILYnoun impartiality adverb impartially

form.definition: adjective If you are impatient, you don't want to wait for something to happen. You want it to happen straight away, or as soon as possible. The audience is getting impatientdon't keep them waiting. The lovers are impatient to get married. Don't be so impatientdinner will be ready in half an hour.

adjective If you are impatient with someone, you get cross with them and are easily annoyed by them. The teacher was very impatient with the less able students. I never dare ask questions because she's so impatient. I'm far too impatient to look after young children.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is patient. ... WORD FAMILYnoun impatience adverb impatiently

form.definition: verb If something impedes someone or something, it slows them down or makes it difficult for them to continue. The rebels destroyed the bridges to impede the progress of the army. I tried to chase the thief, but was impeded by my heavy clothes. His job prospects are impeded by his poor English.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun impediment Beth has a speech impediment. He refused to let his age be an impediment.

form.definition: noun In grammar, the imperative is the form of the verb that is used for telling or ordering a person to do something. For example, in the sentence, 'Wash your hands!', the verb 'wash' is in the imperative.
adjective If something is imperative, it is urgent and must be done before anything else. It's imperative that we get the job done today.

adjective If something is imperfect, there is something wrong with it or it is not complete. We have imperfect towels on special todayfactory seconds all at half price. I have only an imperfect recollection of the incident.

adjective The imperfect tense in English is used to describe continuous actions that took place in the past. The sentence He was walking is an example of the imperfect tense. This tense is also called the past continuous.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun imperfect The verb is in the imperfect.noun imperfection There are a few small imperfections in the weave.

form.definition: adjective Something that is imperial is connected with an empire. Australia once formed part of Britain's imperial possessions.
adjective The imperial system of weights and measures was used in Australia before the metric system was introduced.

adjective If something is impersonal, it doesn't express any emotion, but is very formal or official. Her letter was curiously cold and impersonal. Technical writing usually adopts an impersonal tone.

verb If you impersonate someone, you imitate or pretend to be them. I love watching that comedy show where he impersonates the Prime Minister. The robber gained entry by impersonating an official from the gas company.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun impersonation He does a brilliant impersonation of Elvis Presley.

form.definition: adjective If someone is impertinent, they are rude. The sales assistant was most impertinent to me when I complained. I thought it was impertinent of her to ask me so many personal questions.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun impertinence I've had just about enough of your impertinence, young lady!

form.definition: adjective If you are impetuous, you tend to make decisions and act on them quickly without thinking about things very carefully. Sally's very impetuousit gets her into trouble sometimes.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is impulsive.

form.definition: noun An implement is a tool that you use for a particular purpose. Usually it is quite a simple tool that is operated by hand and has few moving parts. This gift set contains a potato masher, a can opener and other useful kitchen implements. I need some sort of implement to prise the window open.
verb If you implement a plan, you are responsible for putting it into effect. The revised policy will be implemented from the beginning of next month. The new manager implemented several changes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun implementation

form.definition: verb If someone is implicated in doing a bad thing, they are involved in it. They have a share in the responsibility. The three brothers were all implicated in the crime. He didn't tell Ada what he had done, as he didn't want to implicate her. In his confession he implicated several senior figures.

noun An implication of something is a consequence that will happen if the first thing comes about. What are the implications for the future if oil prices double? She hasn't thought through the implications of her action.
adjective If something is implicit, it is communicated in an indirect way. We have an implicit understanding that we don't interfere with each other's work.

adjective If you have implicit faith or trust in someone, you trust them absolutely. You do not doubt them at all. You can place implicit trust in herI've always had the highest regard for her honesty and integrity.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb implicitly I believe impli-citly in the need for environmental controls.

form.definition: verb If you implore someone to do something, you beg or plead with them to do it. He implored me to give him a second chance. Don't turn me away, I implore you. In some cultures imploring is a normal tactic in business negotiations.
verb If you imply something, you hint or suggest it without actually stating it clearly. Pat didn't actually say it was my faultbut he implied it.

verb If something implies something else, the existence of the first thing means that the second thing probably also exists or will exist. Your silence about the budget implies that you approve of it.
adjective If you are impolite, you are rather rude or discourteous. It was most impolite of him to push ahead like that.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is polite.

form.definition: verb If you import something, you bring it into a country from overseas. Generally you have bought it overseas and plan to sell it at a profit in the country to which you import it. He set up a business importing handicrafts from Thailand. Australia imports some oil from overseas. You can import without duty personal effects you've owned for 12 months. x

noun Imports are things that are brought into a country from overseas. Heavy machinery is one of Australia's principal imports. If the value of imports in an economy exceeds the value of exports, there is a trade deficit.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is export. ... WORD FAMILYadjective import ...import duty

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is important, they are famous or of great significance. Federation was an important event in Australian history. June knows a lot of important people. This was an important factor in our decision. There have been important changes lately.
adjective If something is important, it is essential or of great value. It is important to wash the fruit thoroughly. Careful preparation is very important.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun importance adverb importantly

form.definition: verb If you impose something on someone, you force them to accept it, often by passing a law. The Government is planning to impose a new tax on businesses. The rules have been imposed without consultation.

verb If someone imposes on you, they expect too much of you when they ask for favours. At first I was happy to help out, but soon she began to impose on me. I don't want to impose, but could I stay at your place for a few days?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun imposition It's a bit of an imposition, expecting us to babysit for her.

form.definition: adjective If something is imposing, it is grand and impressive. They live in an imposing mansion. He was a tall and imposing figure. She may have an imposing title, but she's only a relatively junior manager.

adjective If something is impossible, it cannot be done or it cannot be true. The opposite of this is possible. It's impossible to solve the problem without more information. It was impossible to move the piano. That's impossibleI saw him here at six.

adjective If you say that someone is impossible, you mean that they are very awkward and difficult to deal with. The baby's crying and she's been impossible all day. She was an impossible boss and most of her staff left within months.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun impossibility I'm afraid bringing the date forward is an absolute impossibility.

form.definition: noun An imposter is someone who deceives people by pretending to be someone else. He says he's a doctor but I think he may be an imposter.
adjective If a man is impotent, he is unable to have sexual intercourse because he cannot have or maintain an erection of his penis.

adjective In formal language, if you say someone is impotent, you mean that they do not have the power or ability to do something. I felt completely impotent in the face of their tragedythere was nothing I could do to help.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun impotence

form.definition: verb If someone or something impresses you, they attract your attention and make you think highly of them. She really impressed me in the way she led the meeting. What impressed me most was the sheer spaciousness of the outback.
verb If you impress something on someone, you emphasise it clearly to them. Leyla impressed on us the risks involved in the project. I must impress on you that this conversation is confidential.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See impression.adjective impressive Her qualifications are impressive.

form.definition: noun Your impression of someone or something is the idea you form about them as a result of your contact with them. What were your impressions of Bali? My first impression of him wasn't favourable. I formed the impression that she was honest. I was under the impression Joe was the manager.

noun An impression is also a mark that is left on a surface as the result of pressing something onto it. I formed an impression of the key in the clay. There was still an impression in the pillow where her head had lain.

make an impression If you make an impression on someone, you attract their attention so that they notice or remember you. His neat appearance made a good impression at the interview. Don't try too hard to make an impression on your first day.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective impressionable Young children are so impressionablethey'll believe anything.

form.definition: verb If you imprison someone, you put them in prison or trap them somewhere. He was imprisoned for three years for the crime. A rock fall imprisoned the explorers in the cave.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun imprisonment

form.definition: verb If something improves, it becomes better. Cora's behaviour has improved lately. I'm working hard to improve my typing. A dash of chilli greatly improves the flavour. Let's hope the weather improves soon.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun improvement There has been a considerable improvement in her condition.

form.definition: adjective If someone is impudent, they are bold and cheeky. The more impudent boys called out to her as she went past.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun impudence

form.definition: noun If you have an impulse to do something, you feel a sudden desire to do it. My first impulse was to laugh, but I saw she wasn't joking. I had a impulse to ring her, and it turned out that she was just writing to me.

on impulse If you do something on impulse, you do it because you suddenly feel like it. You haven't planned to do it and you haven't thought about the consequences. I invited them round on impulse, and now I've got to cook dinner for six! The lollies are attractively displayed in the hope that people will buy them on impulse.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective impulsive She's so impulsiveshe never stops to think things through.noun impulsiveness

form.definition: adjective If a substance is impure, it has other substances mixed with it that spoil its quality. This water is impuredon't drink it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun impurity

form.definition: preposition You use in to say that something is included within certain areas of space or limits of time. It's in the box. He can do that in an hour.
preposition You can also use in to indicate the situation or manner or condition of something. We finished the job in heavy rain. ...in darkness. ...held in secret. ...written in English.
preposition You can also use in to mean 'into'. Put it in the box. Set it in motion.
adjective You can say something is in if you mean it is popular or favoured by people. Thai cooking is very in these days. She used to be in with the right people, but not any more.
ins and outs The ins and outs of a matter are all the things that need to be explained about it. I haven't got time to tell you the ins and outs of the situation, I'm afraid.
prefix The prefix in- sometimes means the same as the preposition 'in', and appears in such words as income, inhabit and so on.
prefix In- also is used as a negative prefix, in the same way as 'un-'. It appears in variant forms such as im-, 'impossible' and ir-, 'irresponsible'.
adjective If something is inaccurate, it has errors in it. It is not correct or accurate.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun inaccuracy There are too many inaccuracies in this typing.

form.definition: adjective If something is inadequate, it is not enough or it does not meet the required standard. The opposite of this is adequate. The food was inadequate for so many hungry people. Her performance in the position has been inadequate. The project is in difficulty because of inadequate funding.

adjective If someone is inadequate, they are not able to cope well with the situations they face. He felt inadequate to the huge job ahead of him. Should we remove children from inadequate parents or should we try to support the family?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun inadequacy (inadequacies)

form.definition: adjective If something is inane, it is very silly or foolish. I could hear her inane laugh. What an inane question to ask!
adjective If something is inanimate, it is not a person or animal. I was surprised to find myself so attached to an inanimate object.
adjective If something is inappropriate, it is not suitable for a particular purpose. The opposite of this is appropriate. My casual clothes were inappropriate for such a formal dinner.
adjective If someone's behaviour is inappropriate, it is not socially acceptable. He made some rather inappropriate jokes about his wife.

verb If something incapacitates you, it makes you unable to do the things you usually do. I was incapacitated with flu for most of last week. This insurance policy covers you if you are incapacitated by illness or injury.

noun An incentive is something that gives you a good reason to do something. We offered our son a bike as an incentive to pass his exams. The wedding coming up was a good incentive to lose weight. What are your earnings, including bonuses and incentives?
adjective In fairly formal language, if you say something is incessant, you mean that it seems never to stop. His incessant talking gets on my nerves. We've had incessant rain all week.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb incessantly

form.definition: noun Incest is sexual intercourse between people who are closely related to each other, such as parents and children or brothers and sisters.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective incestuous

form.definition: noun An inch was an imperial unit of length equal to 2.54 centimetres.
verb If you inch along, you move forward very slowly. We inched along the narrow ledge. I inched through the crowd.
noun The incidence of something is the amount or rate that it happens. There is a low incidence of heart disease among vegetarians.

noun An incident is an event or happening, especially an unexpected one. Police reported two incidents of violence during the protest. We regret the unfortunate incident when you were refused service. There were several amusing incidents on the journey.
without incident If something takes place without incident, it goes along smoothly with nothing unexpected happening. I completed the trip without further incident.

adjective If something is incidental, it happens as a result of something else, but is not very important. There were a few incidental expenses associated with the camp, such as the cost of hiring a tent. These achievements are incidental to our main objective.
verb If you incinerate something, you burn it in order to destroy it completely. They set up a plant to incinerate industrial waste.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun incinerator We'll burn the papers in the incinerator.

form.definition: verb If you incite someone to do something, you stir them up to do something bad that they probably wouldn't have done otherwise. The speaker incited the crowd to riot.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun incitement

form.definition: noun An incline is a fairly gentle slope in a piece of land. You'll need to use a low gear on the incline ahead. It was difficult to push the trolley up the incline.
If you are inclined to do something, doing it is part of your character or habits. He's inclined to be moody. She's inclined to go off on trips at short notice.
adjective If you are inclined to do something, you feel like doing it. There's no proof, but I'm inclined to believe him. I'm not inclined to help her after the way she treated us.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun inclination My inclination is to go home, but I have to stay.

form.definition: verb If something includes something else, it has that thing as one of its parts. The gift pack includes a free hand towel. Does the $20 special include dessert? Make Ping feel welcome, boysinclude him in your game.

including You use including to draw attention to some particular thing that forms part of a larger group. Ten people, including two children, were injured in the blast. I want us all to make a big effortincluding you, Paul! ... WORD FAMILYadjective See inclusive.noun inclusion The inclusion of Gina in the team pleased everyone.

adjective If something is inclusive, it includes all the things that you mention. We offer dinner, theatre tickets, accommodation and breakfast for an inclusive price of $200 per person. Tonight I want you to read pages 48 to 65 inclusive.
adjective If someone speaks in an incoherent manner, they are speaking so unclearly that it is hard to understand what they are saying.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun incoherence

form.definition: noun Your income is the total amount of money you have coming in from all sourcesincluding your job, pensions or allowances, and investments. Tom receives a large income from property investments. Australian residents have to pay tax on their worldwide income.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective income ...income tax.

form.definition: adjective You use incoming to describe someone who has just been appointed or something that is arriving. ...the incoming Prime Minister. ...the incoming tide. ...an incoming phone call.
adjective If someone is incompetent, they are bad at doing their work or a particular thing. He can't even fix a leaking taphe's quite incompetent when it comes to household maintenance.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun incompetence

dictionary.entry: inconvenientINk@n`vi:ni:@nt adjective If something is inconvenient, it causes some difficulties or problems because it doesn't really suit you. Have I come at an inconvenient time? It's inconvenient travelling by bus with all these packages. ... WORD FAMILYnoun inconvenience It is an inconvenience to have to go twenty kilometres out of our way. verb inconvenience I hope we have not inconvenienced you by arriving early.

form.definition: verb If you incorporate something in something else, you make the first thing part of the second thing. I incorporated the statistics in my report. We have incorporated several new features in the latest model.

dictionary.entry: increaseIN`kri:s verb If something increases, it becomes greater. My weight increased over Christmas. We increased our prices at the beginning of the year. ... THE OPPOSITEof this is decrease. ... WORD FAMILY`INkri:s There has been another increase in inflation.adjective increasing I watched with increasing concern.adverb increasingly People are finding it increasingly difficult to afford homes.

form.definition: adjective If something is incredible, it is so amazing that it's hard to believe. By an incredible coincidence, he came along at just that moment.

adjective If something is incredible, it is very impressive or striking in some way. They spent an incredible amount on advertising. Lisa has got incredible talent. They all wore these incredible green and red uniforms.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb incredibly Don't you think Dale's incredibly handsome?

form.definition: verb If you incur something, you bring it upon yourself as a result of what you do. The company incurred large losses last year. I'm reluctant to incur any further expense. His apathy incurred her anger.
adjective If you are indebted to someone, you owe them money. We're so indebted to the bank that even if we sold the house, there'd be nothing left over. The company is heavily indebted.
adjective In formal language, if you say you are indebted to someone, you mean that you're grateful to them for something they've done. I'm indebted to you for your generous help.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun indebtedness How can the poorer nations escape from the cycle of indebtedness?

form.definition: adjective If something is indecent, it is offensive because it doesn't conform to generally accepted moral standards. That's a very revealing swimming costumeI think it's quite indecent. He was arrested for indecent exposure. It's indecent to spend so much on a party when people are starving.
adverb Indeed is used to emphasise what you are saying. If this is indeed the case, we must act at once.
adverb You can use indeed together with very to give even more emphasis to an adjective. I'm very sorry indeed. He's very sick indeed.

adverb Indeed can also be used to mark a contrast between one expression and another with a stronger or opposite meaning. He is a very good, indeed a great, artist. I wasn't lateindeed I was a couple of minutes early.
adjective If something is indefinite, it is not clearly or exactly stated. It is vague. She gave me an indefinite answer. His responsibilities are rather indefinite but he always looks busy.
adjective If something is indefinite, people are not certain how long it will last or when it will end. Patrick has gone overseas for an indefinite period.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb indefinitely He'll be away indefinitely.

form.definition: verb If you indent a line of text, you leave some blank space at the beginning of it. I indent the first line of each paragraph five spaces.
verb If you indent something, you make a mark on it by pressing hard against it. The table had indented the floor covering.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun indentation

form.definition: adjective If something is independent, it is separate. It is not influenced or controlled by outside forces. The government commissioned an independent inquiry into crime. Australia became an independent nation in 1901.

adjective If you are independent, you are able to manage by yourself and like to do things alone. Although mother is ninety, she's still quite independent. Alice is an independent little girlshe packs her own school lunch. We arrange holidays for the independent traveller.
noun In politics, an independent is a candidate or member of parliament who is not formally connected with any political party. The independents held the balance of power.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun independence adverb independently

form.definition: noun The index to a book is an alphabetical list of things mentioned in it, with the numbers of the pages where they appear. It is usually at the back of the book. I looked his name up in the index and found three useful references.
index finger Your index finger is the finger next to your thumb. Another word for this is forefinger.

verb If you indicate something to someone, you draw their attention to it, usually by pointing at it. He indicated the chair, so I sat down. She indicated the spot on the map where the plane had last been seen.

verb If something indicates that something is the case, it shows or suggests it to be true. This research indicates a high level of satisfaction with the existing system. The timing indicates that the symptoms were not caused by the gas.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See indicator.noun indication His trembling hands gave an indication of his real feelings.

form.definition: noun An indicator is something that shows you what the situation is, especially when you are not able to observe it directly. The petrol indicator showed that the tank was nearly empty. This test is a fairly good indicator of general intelligence.
noun The indicators on a car are the flashing lights on each side which you turn on to show that you intend to turn left or right. There's something wrong with the rear left indicator.

adjective If you are indifferent to something, you don't feel any emotion about it. You don't really care about it. He used to upset me but now I feel quite indifferent to him. Frankly I'm quite indifferent whether you go or stay. It was impossible to remain indifferent in the face of such suffering.
adjective If something is indifferent, it is of rather poor quality. Their results this season have been indifferent. The food was indifferent and the service slowI won't go there again.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun indifference

form.definition: adjective If something is indigenous, it is native to the place where it is found. It has existed there since the earliest times and has not been brought from overseas. Eucalypts are indigenous to Australia. Indigenous animals suffer from competition with imported species. The colonists forced the indigenous inhabitants off their land.
noun Indigestion is a pain in your stomach which you get if you cannot digest your food easily, for example because you have eaten too much or too quickly.
adjective If you are indignant about something, you are cross because you think that you have been badly or unfairly treated. He was most indignant that we'd spelled his name wrong on the invitation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun indignation

form.definition: adjective If something is indispensable, it is absolutely necessary. You simply can't manage without it. My car is indispensable to me in my job, so losing my licence was a disaster. No-one's so indispensable that they can't take a week's holiday!
adjective If something is indispensable, it is extremely useful. A food processor is an indispensable gadget.
adjective In formal language, if you say that you are indisposed, you mean that you are ill.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun indisposition

form.definition: adjective If something is indisputable, it is not possible to deny it or argue with it. The facts are indisputable. He presented an indisputable case for the change in policy. It's indisputable that we're in serious trouble.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb indisputably That would be indisputably the best outcome.

form.definition: noun An individual is a person considered alone rather than as part of a group. I want to be treated as an individual, not just as another student. The Commission invites representations from interested individuals and organisations.
noun An individual is a person you consider to be a bit strange. Who's that individual in the long raincoat? She's a real individual!
adjective If something is individual, it is single or separate. The cakes are in individual wrappings for maximum freshness.
adjective If something is individual, it relates to one person only. He needs some individual attention to help with his reading.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun individuality It is important to recognise the individuality of each child.adverb individually I spoke to them individually about their concerns.

form.definition: verb If you indoctrinate someone, you cause them to accept certain ideas or beliefs, instead of allowing them to think for themselves. Peter's been indoctrinated with party dogma ever since he was a teenager.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun indoctrination

form.definition: adjective If someone is indolent, they are very lazy. That indolent bunch need a kick up the backside.
noun Indonesian is the official language of the Republic of Indonesia. You can also refer to it as Bahasa Indonesian.
adjective If someone or something comes from Indonesia, you describe them as Indonesian.
adverb If something happens indoors, it happens inside a building. If it rains, we'll hold the party indoors. I've been indoors all dayI feel like going for a walk.
adverb If you go indoors, you go inside a building. It started to rain, so we went indoors.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is outdoors. ... WORD FAMILYadjective indoor The hotel has a heated indoor pool.

form.definition: verb If you induce something, you cause it to happen. This syrup should induce vomiting. Her nervous manner doesn't exactly induce confidence.

verb In formal language, if you say you induce someone to do something, you mean that you persuade them to do it. Can't I induce you to come to the party? I wonder what induced him to give up such a promising career.
verb If a doctor induces a birth, they cause labour to begin by injecting the woman with hormones.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun inducement They offered a substantial salary rise as an inducement to stay.noun induction The baby was very late, so I had an induction.

form.definition: verb If you indulge someone, you allow them to do or have what they want. His mother indulges him with too much pocket money. I don't know why you want to take on this project, but I'm prepared to indulge you.

verb If you indulge in something, you allow yourself to do it even though some people would think you ought not to. I grew fat through indulging in too much rich food. Apparently he indulges in some very strange sexual practices. ... WORD FAMILYnoun indulgence Chocolate cake is one of my few indulgences.noun indulgent My grandmother was always very indulgent with me.
noun Industry is the work of producing manufactured goods for sale. This is usually done in factories, with the aid of machines. The government should be doing more to support Australian industry.
noun An industry is a particular branch of production or services. The Wheat Board regulates the wheat industry. The tourist industry is experiencing rapid growth.
noun In rather formal language, industry is hard work. He works with industry and determination.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective industrial ...the industrial sector. ...an industrial dispute.verb industrialise (<or> industrialize) ...an industrialised nation.adjective industrious He had been industrious in cleaning up before our arrival.

form.definition: adjective If someone is inept, they are not competent and show no skill or talent. Greg is a totally inept manager. I'm hopelessly inept at gardening. Her performance was embarrassingly inept.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb ineptly

form.definition: adjective If something is inevitable, it is certain to happen. There is nothing you can do to prevent it. If you go about it like that, failure is inevitable. It was inevitable that she'd find out sooner or later.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb See inevitably.

form.definition: adverb If something inevitably happens, things always seem to happen that way. Sue is inevitably the first to finish. Of course it's inevitably in the last place you look.
noun Inexperience is the state of having little or no experience of a particular thing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective inexperienced Don't go on long trips with inexperienced drivers!

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is infamous, they are well known for being evil or unpleasant. This was one of Australia's most infamous murders. Now you'll have a chance to sample the infamous canteen food.

dictionary.entry: infant`Inf@nt noun An infant is a baby or a very young child. She struggled onto the bus with the infant in her arms. It's not very stimulating being at home with the infants all day. ... WORD FAMILYnoun infancy Children should be immunised in infancy. This technology is in its infancy.adjective infantile When I challenged him he went into an infantile sulk.

form.definition: adjective If you are infatuated with someone, your feelings of love for them are so strong that they are the most important thing in your life. Frank's infatuated with his new bride. She's always infatuated with some rock stara different one every month.

adjective If you are infatuated with something, you are very keen on it in a way that other people find a bit ridiculous. Dale's completely infatuated with his new computer. Children often go through a phase of being infatuated with dinosaurs.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun infatuation It's not true love, it's infatuation. He gets sudden infatuations for hobbies.

form.definition: noun An infection is a disease caused by germs.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See infectious.

form.definition: adjective An infectious disease is spread by germs in the atmosphere. You can catch one from someone who has it just by being near them.

adjective A feeling or mood is said to be infectious if it spreads easily from one person to others who are around. His infectious good humour soon had us all feeling much better. She has an infectious laugh.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See infection.verb infect She infected us all with her cold. I was infected by the general gaiety.

form.definition: verb If you infer that something is the case, you draw that conclusion from what you know or observe. I inferred from his good mood that the interview had gone well.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun inference What inferences can we draw from these figures?

form.definition: adjective If something is inferior in relation to something else, it is of a lower standard. This new brand of copy paper is vastly inferior to the old lot. Brenda's so clevershe always makes me feel inferior.
adjective If something is inferior, it is of poor quality. The clothes on sale at the market are very inferior.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is superior. ... WORD FAMILYnoun inferior He regarded the others as his social inferiors.noun inferiority

form.definition: verb If rats, insects or other pests infest a place, they are found there in large numbers. The dog was infested with fleas.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun infestation

dictionary.entry: infidelityInf@`dEl@ti:infidelities noun Infidelity is having sex with someone other than your regular partner, if it is understood with your regular partner that you will have sex only with each other. She forgave him his many infidelities.

form.definition: verb If someone infiltrates a group or organisation, they join it and become involved in its activities in order to harm or destroy it. Government agents had infiltrated the drug ring in order to gather evidence.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun infiltration

form.definition: adjective If something is infinite, it has no limit. The series of prime numbers is infinite. She showed infinite patience with the child. We don't have infinite resources at our command.
adjective If something is infinite, it appears to have no end. He seems to be able to remember an infinite amount of detail.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb infinitely This option is infinitely preferable.noun infinity Parallel lines meet at infinity. There are an infinity of issues to resolve.

form.definition: noun The infinitive is a verb form which is not inflected. In English, the infinitive , except and the auxiliary .
verb If a part of your body is inflamed, it is swollen and red because it is infected by a germ. Her tonsils are severely inflamed.

verb In rather formal language, if you say something inflames someone, you mean that it makes them angry or passionate. The speaker inflamed the crowd as he urged them to attack his opponents. Her struggles inflamed his anger.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun inflammation This antiseptic ointment should reduce the inflammation.adjective inflammatory His inflammatory remarks made the situation worse.

form.definition: adjective If something is inflammable, it burns easily. Petrol is highly inflammable.
form.note: ... THE PREFERRED TERMfor this is flammable. Inflammable is NOT the opposite of flammable.

form.definition: verb If you inflate something such as a balloon or a tyre, you fill it with air or gas so that it becomes larger or firmer. You can use a foot pump to inflate the mattress. The life jacket will inflate automatically when the cord is pulled.
verb If prices inflate, they increase. Our costs have inflated by over 10% in the last year. Strong localised demand has inflated house prices in the region.

inflated If something is inflated, it is greater than you think it ought to be. Jim has an inflated egohe really thinks he's got the answer to everything. I'm not going to buy tomatoes at those inflated prices.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See inflation.

form.definition: noun Inflation is a general increase in prices and in the cost of living. Inflation eats away at the value of savings.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective inflationary ...the inflationary spiral. ...inflationary pressures.

form.definition: verb If a word inflects, its ending or some other part changes to show a different grammatical function. In English, the plural nouns are usually inflected with '-s' or '-es'.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun inflection

form.definition: adjective If something is inflexible, you can't easily bend or distort it. The camera is supported on an inflexible beam.

adjective If someone is inflexible, they are not willing to make changes in order to adapt to a new situation. I tried to persuade him, but he was inflexible. It was her inflexible habit to dine at precisely eight o'clock. The regulations are completely inflexible.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is flexible. ... WORD FAMILYnoun inflexibility

form.definition: verb If you inflict something on someone, you cause them to suffer it. The enemy inflicted heavy casualties on our troops. Janos insisted on inflicting his holiday photos on us.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun infliction

form.definition: verb If something influences something else, it has an effect on it. It plays a role in determining the way things happen. The iron filings are influenced by the magnet. Her apology influenced us favourably. I don't want to influence you either way. He refused to be influenced by financial gain.
noun Influence is the power to affect the way things happen. I have no influence over what they decide to do. He rose to a position of some influence.
noun An influence is something that affects the way things happen. What have been the most important influences in your life? Aboriginal art has had an important influence on my work.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective influential Newspapers have an influential role in society.adjective influential He enjoys his influential position in the company.

form.definition: noun Influenza is a formal word for flu.

noun An influx of people or things is a large number of them arriving at a place. The coastal towns experience an influx of holiday makers each summer. We had to take on extra workers to deal with the influx of orders after we were featured on national TV.

verb If you inform someone about something, you tell them about it, often in an official way. We regret to inform you that your application has not been successful. Police will not release names until the victims' relatives have been informed.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See information.adjective informative We were given a very informative lecture on blood transfusions.

form.definition: adjective If something is informal, it is casual and relaxed. It was a very informal gathering, just a few friends around for a barbie. People use a lot of abbreviations in informal language.
adjective If a vote is informal, it doesn't count because you haven't filled in the ballot paper in the right way.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is formal. ... WORD FAMILYadverb informally

form.definition: noun Information is facts about something. I need some information about pensions. Please send me further information on your products. I checked the information in an encyclopedia.
verb If someone or something infuriates you, they make you very cross. Jane infuriates mewhy can't she ever be on time? It infuriates me to see him wasting his talent.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective infuriating There was a further infuriating delay. The kids can be infuriating at times.

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is ingenious, they are very clever in the way they solve a problem. Liz came up with an ingenious solution. It was ingenious of you to think of using the chisel. This is an ingenious little gadget for peeling potatoes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun ingenuity The puzzle defied even Ted's ingenuity.

form.definition: adjective If dirt is ingrained, it has worked its way into the surface of something so that it's hard to remove. First we had to remove the ingrained grime.

verb If you ingratiate yourself with someone, you behave in a way that will make them like you, usually so that you can get what you want. It's worth ingratiating yourself with the landlord. Being late on the first day isn't exactly going to ingratiate you.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective ingratiating He gave an ingratiating smile.[xp\start\ingratitude

form.definition: noun If someone shows ingratitude, they are not thankful or grateful for something that has been done to help them. Such ingratitudeafter all I've done for him!
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is gratitude.

form.definition: noun An ingredient is one part of a mixture of things. In particular it is one type of food that is used to make a prepared dish. The ingredients are listed at the top of each recipe. I always check the ingredients of packaged foods before I buy them. Humour is one of the ingredients of a lasting romance.

verb If people inhabit a place, they live there. Australia was inhabited by Aborigines for thousands of years before the invasion of the Europeans. ... WORD FAMILYnoun inhabitant Mary is one of the oldest inhabitants of the villageshe knows its history.
verb If you inhale, you breathe in. The doctor got me to inhale while he listened to my chest with his stethoscope. I hate inhaling the smoky air in pubs.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is exhale. ... WORD FAMILY noun inhalation

form.definition: verb If you inherit property, you receive it from someone who has died. I inherited this cottage from my uncle.
verb If you inherit a trait or characteristic, you get it from your parents because of your genes. Unfortunately Taryn inherited her father's large nose.
verb If you inherit something such as a problem, it is passed on to you to deal with. The new government has inherited an economic mess.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun inheritance He squandered his inheritance.

form.definition: adjective The initial thing is the first thing that occurs. Usually this initial thing is contrasted with something later which is different in some way. The initial inquiry concerned the causes of the company's collapse. Her initial reaction was grief, but soon she became angry.
noun An initial is the first letter of a word or name. In English the names of the months have upper-case initials. The initials 'AMA' stand for 'Australian Medical Association'.

noun Someone's initials are the first letters of their given name and surname (and sometimes a middle name as well). You often use people's initials, which are written as capital letters, to refer to them in notes. I didn't know what was meant by 'AP to check with PM' because I didn't recognise the initials.
verb If you initial something, you write the first letters of your names on it in capitals. She initialled the report 'BG'. You have to initial each alteration on a cheque.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb initially Initially Raul felt he had no chance of winning, but later he grew optimistic.

form.definition: verb If you initiate something, you start it or get it going. The new manager immediately initiated a program of reform.

noun If you have initiative, you are able to think and act for yourself. You are willing to take action and be responsible for it. The position calls for someone with energy and initiative to revive the department. She showed plenty of initiative in solving the problem.
noun An initiative is a move towards solving a problem or getting something done. The committee welcomed the initiative put forward by the president.

take the initiative If you take the initiative, you gain control of a situation by acting yourself instead of waiting for someone else to do something. I decided to take the initiative in approaching him. When the chairman was sick we took the initiative and made several new appointments.
verb If you inject something into someone or inject someone with something, you put it into their body using a needle and syringe. The doctor injected the antibiotic into her arm.
verb If you inject something into something, you supply more of it. The government has injected badly needed funds into the TAFE system. Try to inject more enthusiasm into your voice.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun injection What injections do I need for the trip? We need an injection of capital.

form.definition: verb If someone or something injures you, they cause you some physical harm. One person was killed in the accident and six injured. I injured my foot when I fell downstairs.

injured If you feel injured about something, you are sad and upset because you think you haven't been treated as well as you deserve. Paula's still feeling injured that she wasn't chosen to be in the play.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun injury (injuries) He had severe head injuries.

form.definition: noun An injustice is something that is very unfair. Injustice is a fact of life in many countries. He claimed that he had been done an injustice.
noun Ink is a black or coloured liquid used in pens or with a brush for writing and drawing. Write your answers in ink, not pencil. The poems are beautifully illustrated in ink.
noun Ink is a pigment used in printing. The ink is forced through these nozzles. I got ink all over my hands when I changed the cartridge.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb ink This roller inks the surface.

form.definition: noun If you have an inkling that something will happen, you have a suspicion or intuition about it. I must admit I had an inkling he wouldn't come. I haven't got an inkling where she is now.
adjective If a decoration is inlaid, it is set into something so that it doesn't project beyond its surface. The desk lid had an inlaid design made from small pieces of different coloured wood.
adjective If something is inland, it is situated away from the coast of a country. The inland regions have been badly affected by the drought.
adverb If you move inland, you move across an area of land away from the coast. The explorers decided to venture inland.
noun Your in-laws are the parents of your husband or wife. My in-laws are coming to visit from Italy next year.
noun An inmate is someone who lives in a prison, nursing home or other institution. He was segregated from the other inmates for his own protection.
adjective If something is described as inner, it is located inside something else. Beyond the first door was another door leading to the inner office. I had an infection of the inner ear.
adjective Inner also describes things concerned with your mind, emotions and character. I attempted to hide my inner feelings. His inner strength helped him to cope with the ordeal.
noun In cricket, an innings is a period of time when the players of one side have their turn to bat and score runs.

adjective If someone is innocent, they haven't done what they're accused of, or they haven't done any harm. They are not guilty. She was arrested and charged, but she swears she's innocent. He insisted he was innocent of all blame for the mix-up. Thousands of innocent civilians were killed.
adjective If someone is innocent, they are not familiar with bad or unpleasant things. They are naive and trusting. She was so innocent that he was able to trick her out of a fortune.

adjective If something is innocent, it is not intended to cause harm or not capable of causing harm. My question was perfectly innocentI don't know why he took offence. We thought the package might be a letter bomb, but it turned out to be innocent.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun innocence

form.definition: adjective If things are innumerable, there are very many of them. I'm tired of answering his innumerable questions. She turned up with innumerable suitcases.
verb If you inoculate someone against a disease, you inject them with a serum which protects them from catching the disease. I've been inoculated against hepatitis B.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun inoculation

form.definition: noun An in-patient is someone who is admitted to a hospital for treatment. They live at the hospital for a period of time while they are being treated.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is out-patient.

form.definition: noun An inquest is an official inquiry into something to see exactly what happened and how it came about. There will be a coroner's inquest into the man's death.

verb If you inquire into something, you try to find out more about it, often in a fairly formal way such as by carrying out a research project. They set up a commission to inquire into the problems of Aboriginal health. When I inquired into the matter I found that the situation was more complex.

verb If you inquire about something, you ask someone a question. You can also use the spelling enquire for this meaning. 'Is this the road to Wollongong?' he inquired. I'm ringing to inquire about your range of computers. Archie inquired after you the other day.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun inquiry (inquiries)

form.definition: adjective If someone is inquisitive, they ask a lot of questions and want to find out as much as possible about things. He's an inquisitive little boy, always full of questions. Don't be so inquisitivethat's really not your business.

noun If you speak about the ins and outs of a matter, you mean the more complicated details associated with it. Vijaya had heard that the project had gone bankrupt but did not know the ins and outs of the final collapse.
adjective If someone is insane, they are seriously mentally ill and unable to function normally in society. His brother became insane in middle age. She was almost insane with grief.

adjective In informal language, if you say someone or something is insane, you mean they are utterly foolish. That was an insane thing to doyou could have caused a serious accident! He's got this insane scheme for raising money by recycling yogurt cartons.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun insanity

form.definition: noun An insect is a small creature with six legs and a body divided into three parts. Most insects have wings. There are too many insects out in the bush!
noun An insecticide is a chemical that is used to kill insects. The crops are sprayed with insecticide.
adjective If you feel insecure, you lack confidence in your own abilities and in the affection of other people. His parents' divorce made Tom very insecure.

adjective If something is insecure, it is not established firmly enough to survive pressure or difficulties. This fencing is insecureit could blow down in a high wind. His position seems rather insecurethe company has already retrenched fifty staff.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is secure. ... WORD FAMILYnoun insecurity (insecurities)

form.definition: adjective If someone is insensitive, they do not show much understanding or consideration for other people and their feelings. How insensitive can you get, talking about funerals the week after his mother died!
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is sensitive.

form.definition: verb If you insert something into something else, you put the first thing inside the second thing. She inserted her key into the lock. Insert your card as shown, and key in your PIN.

verb If you insert some extra text into a piece of writing, you include or add it. You could insert a summary of his speech here. As you insert characters the program automatically takes care of the line breaks.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun insertion

form.definition: preposition If something is inside something else, it is in the internal part of it. It is surrounded by it. We sheltered inside the fortifications. He ran inside the house. There's a free gift inside the packet. I felt better with some food inside me.

adverb If something is inside, it is in the internal part of something. I prodded the parcel to try and guess what was inside. I opened my case and put the book inside. On the surface he appeared to be coping, but inside he was terrified.
adverb If something is inside, it is indoors. It's a shame to stay inside on such a lovely day. It started raining, so we went inside.
adjective If something is described as inside, it is in the inner part of something. The key's in the inside pocket of my jacket. Lola's running in the inside lane.
noun The inside of something is the inner part. The inside of the apple was all brown. Jon knows the company from the inside.

insides In informal language, your insides are the organs inside your body, especially your intestines. I don't want a surgeon poking around in my insides. The wounded man was brought in with half his insides hanging out.

inside out If something is inside out, it has been turned so that what is normally the inner part is now on the outside. You've got your jumper on inside out. It's a reversible designyou can turn it inside out.
If you know something inside out, you are thoroughly familiar with it. By the end of your apprenticeship, you'll know your trade inside out. I know Newcastle inside outI was brought up there.

verb If someone insinuates something, they hint or imply something bad about someone without saying it directly. She insinuated that his cheating might have been going on for even longer than we thought. Just what are you insinuating?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun insinuation

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is insipid, they are dull and uninteresting. Bob's a pretty insipid character. It still tastes pretty insipidlet's add some more chilli.

verb If you insist on doing something or that someone should do something, you demand it forcefully or you do it even though other people oppose you or try to dissuade you. She insisted on seeing the manager. He insisted on leaving at once, although he was very tired. I must insist on payment without delay. Very well, if you insist.
verb If you insist that something is the case, you state very firmly that it's so. You refuse to give in or change your mind. She insisted that her son was innocent of the charges.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun insistence At his insistence we checked back through all the records.adjective insistent The kids generally get their own waythey're very insistent.

form.definition: adjective If someone is insolent, they are very rude and insulting. When I asked him not to park there he was insolent. The protesters made insolent gestures at the police.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun insolence

form.definition: verb If you inspect something, you look at it carefully to see whether it is in an acceptable state. Make sure you inspect the car for faults before you buy it. When can I inspect the property?

verb An official inspects things to check that they are in good order and everything is being properly done. Health department officials inspect local cafes and restaurants regularly. I had my ticket inspected on the bus.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun inspection I've got to take my car for a registration inspection.noun inspector

form.definition: verb If someone inspires you, their success or enthusiasm encourages you to try to do the same as them. Jill's marvellous garden inspired me to do something about my own tangled patch. I was inspired to go to college by my English teacher.
verb If something inspires a certain emotion in you, it causes you to feel it. The beautiful weather inspired a much better mood. His manner doesn't exactly inspire confidence.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun inspiration Her work is an inspiration to us all.adjective inspired This restaurant was an inspired choicewe must come again!adjective inspiring His enthusiasm is really inspiringhe really makes you want to learn more.[xp\start\install

form.definition: verb If you install something such as a machine or a computer program, you put it into the place where it will be used and you get it ready for use. The plumber installed my new washing machine in the laundry.
verb If someone is installed into a job or position, there is an official ceremony to mark their appointment. The new bishop was installed last week.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun installation

form.definition: noun An instalment is one event in a sequence that happens at regular intervals. I paid off the loan in four $100 monthly instalments. Buy our next issue for the second instalment of the story.
noun An instance of something is an example of it. It is a case where it happens. I could point to many instances of bad management on his part.

for instance You use for instance when you want to give an example of what you're talking about. Another expression for this is for example. Lots of the children are clevertake Nette, for instance. There are lots of things to dofor instance, you could go to the beach or ride your bike.

dictionary.entry: instant`Inst@nt noun An instant is a very short period of time. The bell should go any instant now. It was all over in an instant. It'll only take an instant to explain. ... WORD FAMILYadjective instant ...instant pain relief. ...instant coffee.adverb instantly I instantly felt better.

form.definition: adverb You use instead to emphasise that what actually happens or what you choose is different from what might have happened or the other things you could choose. Jane couldn't go herself so she sent me instead. I thought I'd win the race, but instead I came last. I put back the red one and took the blue one instead.
instead of You use instead of to introduce an alternative that hasn't happened or won't happen. I stayed at home instead of going out. I bought a jacket instead of a coat.
noun An instinct is a pattern of behaviour that animals have as soon as they are born. They don't have to learn it. The tiny kangaroo finds its way to the mother's pouch by instinct.

noun An instinct is something that you do as an automatic reaction to a situation, without even thinking about it. By instinct I put out my hands as I fell. My first instinct was to run, but then I decided to stand my ground.

noun Your instinct is a feeling you get about something, even though you don't have much information. Another word for this is intuition. My instinct tells me that he's not being honest with us. Sometimes you just have to go with your instincts.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective instinctive

form.definition: noun An institute is an organisation that is involved in activities such as research and teaching. The Medical Research Institute is attached to the university. She's a member of the Institute of Engineers.
verb In formal language, if you say you institute something, you mean that you set it up. The library is instituting a new borrowing system next week.
noun An institution is a large company or organisation. There has been increased competition between financial institutions. You can undertake tertiary education at a variety of institutions.
noun An institution is also a place such as a prison or long-stay hospital where large numbers of people live under supervision. She spent many years in a mental institution.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective institutional Institutional care of mentally ill patients is no longer favoured.verb institutionalise (<or> institutionalize) He had become institutionalised and was unable to function in the outside world.

form.definition: If you instruct someone to do something, you tell or command them to do it. He instructed us to wait here for him.

verb If you instruct someone about something or how to do something, you teach them. The ranger instructed us about safety rules for the bush. I can do it myself if you'll just instruct me how to go about it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See instruction.adjective instructive The computer demonstration was most instructive and helpful.noun instructor ...a driving instructor.
