form.definition: noun An instruction is a command about what is to be done. We are waiting for instructions from head office. Why have you disobeyed my instructions?

noun Instructions are a sequence of commands that you need to follow in order to complete a task. The kit contains everything you need and instructions for assembly. If all else fails, read the instructions!
noun An instrument is a tool or device used to do a particular job. The dentist's instruments were lying on top of the table. The weights are checked with a precision instrument.

noun An instrument is also a device to measure and control all aspects of a complex task such as flying a plane or operating a nuclear plant. The control panel was crowded with all the different instruments.

noun An instrument or musical instrument is something that you play to make music, such as a piano, violin or flute. The musicians packed up their instruments. You have to audition on two instruments.
adjective If someone is insubordinate, they refuse to obey the orders of someone who holds a more senior position at work. The boss fired two of the new workers because they were insubordinate.

adjective If you say that something is insubstantial, you mean that it is not very big or solid. The meal they served was insubstantial and would not have satisfied anyone. ...insubstantial structures.
adjective You can also use insubstantial to mean that something is less important or worthy. Some of the matters before the committee are quite insubstantial and not worth wasting time over.
adjective If you describe something as insubstantial, you can also mean that it does not appear to be real or to be part of reality. ...the insubstantial stuff of dreams.
adjective If someone is insufferable, you find them very annoying and you hate to be in their company. Jason's an insufferable boreI can't stand him.

verb If you insulate something electrical, you surround it with something that doesn't conduct electricity in order to prevent people from getting electric shocks. He used the plastic tape to insulate the cable.

verb If you insulate a building or room, you surround it with material that absorbs heat, in order to keep it hot or cold, or with material that absorbs sound waves, in order to keep it quiet or prevent noise from escaping. We put fibreglass batts in the ceiling to insulate the house from the summer heat.

verb If you insulate someone from something, you prevent them from coming into contact with it in order to protect them. It's impossible to insulate children from what's happening in the world. His staff had insulated him from the news. ... WORD FAMILYnoun insulation
noun Insulin is a hormone produced in your pancreas. It regulates the amount of sugar in your body. If you do not produce enough insulin you suffer from diabetes.

verb If you insult someone, you say something rude to or about them or you do something to show your contempt for them. He descended to insulting his opponents instead of debating the issues. I'm sure she didn't mean to insult meshe simply forgot my name.
noun An insult is a rude remark or an action showing contempt. The children screamed insults at one another across the playground. He took it as an insult that he hadn't been invited.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective insulting The union leader described the management's offer as insulting.

dictionary.entry: insureIn`S@:, -SU@ verb If you insure something such as your house or car, you take out a policy with an insurance company. You pay them a premium, and they will pay you a sum of money if the property is damaged or stolen. Is your bicycle insured? You have to insure particularly valuable items separately. ... WORD FAMILYnoun insurance ...medical insurance. ...travel insurance. ...life insurance.adjective insurance ...an insurance company. ...an insurance policy.

form.definition: adjective If something is intact, it isn't damaged or altered in any way. The vase was delivered to me intact.
adjective If something is integral to something else, it forms part of it and it is needed for the larger whole to be successful. Support from parents is integral to a child's progress at school.

verb If you integrate several things, you join them together so that they form one thing. The state transport systems have been integrated and are now run by one department. These findings appeared too late to be integrated in the report, but they are given in an appendix.

verb If someone integrates into a society, they become a part of it and join in its activities. Our family had no problems integrating into Australian society. There is a move to integrate handicapped children into the mainstream school system. ... WORD FAMILYnoun integration
noun Integrity is the quality of honesty and not being open to corruption. I respect him for his integrity in standing aside.
noun Your intellect is your ability to think, reason and understand things. Although he is physically handicapped, he has a wonderful intellect.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective intellectual He's too intellectual for mehe's only interested in books!

form.definition: noun Intelligence is the ability to learn and understand new concepts and adapt to new situations. Sam is a child of above-average intelligence. She's doing research in the field of artificial intelligence.
noun Intelligence is also good mental powers and ability. She handled the problem with intelligence. Use your intelligenceof course it won't all fit in!
adjective Someone who is intelligent can understand and learn things well. Larry's the most intelligent student in the class. That's a very intelligent question.

verb If you intend to do something, you plan to do it. You have it in mind to do it. I intend to go to Singapore next month. I've been intending to ring him all week. What do you intend to do about the situation?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See intention.adjective intended My remark had the intended effect. That wasn't the intended result.

form.definition: adjective If something is intense, it is very great or severe. I had such an intense pain in my stomach that I could hardly walk. When I saw what had happened I felt intense anger. He studied the document with intense concentration.
adjective If someone is intense, they are very serious and earnest. They are not at all relaxed or easy-going. Cara makes me nervousshe's so intense about everything. He was a very intense young man.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb intensely I dislike him intensely.noun intensity The electric current varies in its intensity.

form.definition: adjective If something is intensive, it involves a lot of concentrated effort in a fairly short time. My intensive study for the month before the exam paid off. We offer an intensive eight-week course in Thai.

intensive care Intensive care is a unit in a hospital where the patients are observed and attended to constantly because they are very sick or have just had a serious operation. I woke up in intensive care. She'll have to spend a few days in intensive care before going back to the ward.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb intensively He's studying intensively for his exam.

form.definition: noun Your intention is what you mean to do or achieve. My intention was to catch the ball. He's full of good intentions but he never gets things done.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See intend.

form.definition: verb When people interact, they respond to each other socially. The class is interacting well with the teacher.
verb If things interact, they act together and have a combined effect. The chemicals interacted to form a poisonous gas. These social factors interact to produce increasing deprivation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun interaction We observed the interactions between the group members.adjective interactive This computer program is fully interactive.

form.definition: verb If you intercept something, you catch or stop it as it goes from one place to another. The drugs shipment was intercepted at the border. I intercepted the ball as Ray threw it to Joe. She intercepted me in the hall.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun interception

form.definition: noun Intercourse is having sex with someone.
noun Intercourse is also an old-fashioned word for being with people and talking to them.

noun If you have an interest in a subject, you find it absorbing. You give it your attention and you want to find out more about it. Australian history is one of my interests. I'm sure this talk will be of interest to you. They showed a lot of interest in my suggestion. I followed the story with interest.
noun If you have an interest in a decision, you are affected by it. We want to attend the meetingafter all, we have an interest in its outcome.
noun If you have an interest in a company, you hold shares in it. The founder's family retains a controlling interest.

noun Interest is a payment for the use of money. If you borrow money from a bank or credit union, you have to repay it with interest; if you deposit money with them, they pay you interest on it (at a lower rate). Interest is credited to your account quarterly. What rate of interest do you charge?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb interest Science doesn't interest me. Can I interest you in a free trial offer?adjective interested Are you interested in sport? Would you be interested in taking part?

form.definition: adjective If something is interesting, it holds your attention, usually because you find it unusual or exciting. ...an interesting movie. ...interesting people. ...an interesting discussion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb interestingly

form.definition: verb If someone interferes in something, they get involved in it without being asked, when it really isn't any of their business. I want to do it myself without her interfering.

verb If something interferes with something else, it prevents it from working or functioning properly. The noise is interfering with my concentration. The impurities interfere with the chemical reaction.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun interference I can do without his interference. Interference distorted the broadcast.adjective interfering She's an interfering busybody!

dictionary.entry: interim`Int@r@m adjective In formal language, if something is described as interim, it is temporary. It is intended to last for a short time only, until a longer-term arrangement is made. We have an interim agreement until the contracts can be signed. Power is in the hands of an interim government. As an interim measure, Rose will approve all expenses.

interiorIn`tI@ri:@ noun The interior of something is the inside part of it. The interior of the cave was cool and damp. Australia's interior is extremely hot and dry. The building features original interiors. ... THE OPPOSITE of this is exterior.

form.definition: noun An interjection is an exclamation. Often it is a sound rather than a word. He made little interjections of surprise as he continued his exploration.
noun In grammar, an interjection is a word or phrase that stands on its own and doesn't form part of the structure of a sentence.
noun An interjection is a remark made by someone while someone else is speaking at the same time. There were so many interjections in the debate that the chair had to call for order.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb interject

form.definition: noun An interlude is a short break between other events or activities. The lunch break was a pleasant interlude in a busy day. There was an interlude while the judges conferred.
adjective If something is described as intermediate, it occurs between other stages or levels. You should not just give the answer but show the intermediate steps in your reasoning.

adjective If a course is described as intermediate, it is intended for students who have some knowledge of the subject. The level is higher than on an elementary course, but lower than on an advanced one. This dictionary is targeted at intermediate learners of English.
noun An intermission is a pause or interval, especially in a show or at the movies.

adjective If something is intermittent, it happens from time to time. It doesn't happen constantly or continuously. He gets intermittent work at the factory, but it's not the same as a full-time job. I've been having intermittent pain in my knee. It's hard to track down these intermittent faults.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb intermittently

form.definition: adjective If something is internal, it is inside something. We knocked down the internal walls. He was suffering from internal bleeding. The company reorganised its internal financial system.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is external.

form.definition: adjective If something is international, it involves different countries or nations. The international conference took place in Geneva. This is the first time I've competed at international level. The movie has met with international success.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb internationally He is internationally famous.

form.definition: verb If you interpret something in a certain way, you understand it like that. You think that that's its meaning. She interpreted my words as a compliment. I didn't know how to interpret his apparent coldness.
verb If you interpret for people who speak different languages, you repeat what each of them says, using the language of the other. I can't speak Korean but luckily we had Chang to interpret for us.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun interpreter Eun works as a conference interpreter.noun interpretation That's my interpretation of the situation.

dictionary.entry: interrogateIn`tEr@gEIt verb If you interrogate someone, you question them closely. The police interrogated the suspect for several hours. When I got home my mother interrogated me about where I'd been and who with. ... WORD FAMILYnoun interrogation The interrogation lasted for three hours.noun interrogator One of the interrogators was particularly nasty.

form.definition: noun In grammar, an interrogative is a word that can be used in a question, for example 'who', 'which', 'why' and 'how'.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective interrogative ...an interrogative pronoun. ...an interrogative sentence.

form.definition: verb If you interrupt someone, you start speaking while they are still in the middle of saying something. In Australian society it is considered rude to interrupt people. The teacher told Ten-Hu to stop interrupting her.

verb If you interrupt something, you stop it or disturb it in the middle. I had to interrupt the program as it had gone off into a loop. I'm not to be interrupted during this interview, please. The meeting was interrupted by a fire alarm.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun interruption

form.definition: noun An intersection is a place where two or more things meet or cross each other. The intersection of the lines marks the centre of the triangle. We need to turn right at the next intersection.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb intersect The two roads intersect a few kilometres north of here.

form.definition: adjective If something is interstate, it concerns different states and territories. Interstate discussions were held in Canberra.
adverb If someone is interstate, they are away from their home state and in another state. Bob's interstate at the momenthe'll be back on Friday.
adverb Interstate means to or from another state. We deliver locally and interstate.

noun An interval is the distance or period of time between things. He planted the bushes at regular intervals along the path. They were reunited after an interval of ten years. The intervals between the contractions became shorter.
noun An interval is also a break between the parts of a show or movie. Another word for this is intermission.
verb If you intervene in something such as a dispute, you try to stop or resolve the conflict. It's a waste of time intervening in the kids' squabblesI just leave them to it.
verb In rather formal language, if you say someone intervenes in a discussion, you mean that they take part in it. So far Katy hadn't intervened at all.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun intervention

dictionary.entry: interview`Int@vju: noun An interview is a meeting where someone is asked questions. The minister gave an interview to the waiting journalists. I read the interview with her in the paper. They asked me to do a market research interview. How did the job interview go? ... WORD FAMILYverb interview noun interviewer

form.definition: noun Your intestine is the long tube in your body which carries food from the stomach to the anus. The word is often used in the plural, intestines, to refer to the loops and coils of the intestine. ...the small intestine. ...the large intestine. His intestines were spilling out of the wound.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is gut. ... WORD FAMILYadjective intestinal

form.definition: adjective If two people are intimate, they have a very close relationship. Vishal and Neelam have been intimate for many years. He's an intimate friend of the Prime Minister.
adjective If two people are intimate, they have a sexual relationship. We'd known each other for years, but we only became intimate recently.

adjective If something is intimate, it is very private and personal. The restaurant has a delightfully intimate atmosphere. She shared her most intimate thoughts with me. She told the reporter all the intimate details of their relationship.
adjective If you have an intimate knowledge of something, you know it thoroughly and in detail. He has an intimate knowledge of the wildlife in the area.

verb In formal language, if you say someone intimates something, you mean they allow it to be known, often in response to questioning, rather than stating it in a direct way. He intimated that he knew the girl well.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun intimacy adverb intimately

dictionary.entry: intimidateIn`tIm@dEIt verb If someone intimidates you, they scare or frighten you, often to make you do what they want. Many witnesses withdrew their statements because they were intimidated by the gang. ... WORD FAMILYadjective intimidated I felt intimidated by her superior knowledge.adjective intimidating I found the formal atmosphere of the courtroom very intimidating.

form.definition: preposition You use into to indicate movement or direction, as a combination of the words 'in to'. He put the money into his wallet. She walked into the house. Gina has to go into hospital for an operation.
preposition In informal language, if you say you are into something, you mean you are very interested or involved with it. He's really into health foods.
preposition You use into when you divide one number by another. How many times does six go into eighteen? Three times!

noun Your intonation is the way your voice goes up and down in pitch when you speak. Intonation is one of the hardest aspects of pronunciation for learners to master. Use a rising intonation for the question.

adjective In formal language, if you say someone is intoxicated, you mean that they are drunk or affected by some other drug. We reserve the right to refuse service to patrons who appear to be intoxicated.
adjective An intransitive verb has no grammatical object.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is transitive. ... WORD FAMILYadverb intransitively This verb is used intransitively.

form.definition: adjective Intravenous medication is given directly into the bloodstream, through a needle inserted in a vein. He's on an intravenous drip.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb intravenously She has to be fed intravenously.

dictionary.entry:
intrigueIn`tri:g; <for sense 2>, /\times,0\ntrg, ntrig/ (verb forms\optima0\intriguesintriguedintriguing
verb If something intrigues you, you are fascinated by it. You are very curious to find out more about it. I was intrigued by what she said about her family background.
noun An intrigue is a secret plan to do something that will harm someone. There was an atmosphere of intrigue and suspicion at the meeting.
... WORD FAMILYadjective intriguing There's a certain intriguing mystery about him.

form.definition: verb If you introduce two people to each other, you tell each of them the other's name when they meet for the first time. In work situations you're supposed to introduce the person of lower status to the one of higher status. Claude, may I introduce my cousin, Jolanta? Jolanta, this is Claude, an old friend from college. Let me introduce you to our managing director.
verb If you introduce someone to something, you cause them to experience it for the first time. It was Paolo who introduced me to Italian cooking.

verb In rather formal language, if you say someone introduces something somewhere, you mean they bring it there. The bill will be introduced into Parliament in the next session. Cats and dogs were introduced to Australia by the early settlers.
verb If you introduce something, you put it into use. They're introducing a new payroll system.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See introduction.

form.definition: noun An introduction is the first or most elementary part of something. In the introduction to his speech, he welcomed us all. The course is called 'An Introduction to Psychology'. We asked her to write an introduction to the book.

noun The introduction of something is its being brought somewhere or put into use. The introduction of cane toads to Queensland was a mistake. We set a target date of June for the introduction of the new system.

noun An introduction to someone is being put in contact with them by someone who knows you both. After the introductions we went in to dinner. I can get you introductions to some very influential people.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective introductory

dictionary.entry: intrudeIn`tru:d verb If you intrude, you interrupt someone when they are busy with some other activity. I don't want to intrude while he's working. I'm sorry to intrude, but can I just get my bag? ... WORD FAMILYnoun intruder Our house was broken into last night and the intruder was caught by police.noun intrusion Frankly I resented the intrusion.adjective intrusive The noise from the fair is very intrusive.

form.definition: noun Your intuition is your ability to understand situations in a way that doesn't rely on logical reasoning. Sometimes you have to rely on your intuition. My intuition told me that there was something wrong. I had an intuition that things wouldn't work out for him.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective intuitive She's a very intuitive person. My intuitive feeling is to give it a go.

dictionary.entry: invadeIn`vEId verb An army invades a country when it enters it by force and takes over. The Japanese invaded Singapore in 1942. ... WORD FAMILYnoun invader The invaders crushed all opposition.noun invasion

form.definition: adjective If something is invalid, it doesn't count because it hasn't been done in the correct way. The election was declared invalid, as not enough members had voted.
adjective If something is invalid, it is not logically sound. His conclusion is invalid, as it is based on incorrect assumptions.
noun Invalid is a rather old-fashioned word for a sick person who needs to be looked after. She spent her final years as an invalid in the care of her daughter.

noun An invalid pension is a pension that you can get if you're blind or permanently unable to work because of ill health. If you became ill before coming to Australia, you can't get the pension until you've been here for ten years.
adjective If something is invaluable, it is extremely useful. Harry's assistance was invaluable to me. A penknife can be an invaluable tool.
verb If you invent a device, you are the first person to think of it and design it. He invented a new type of engine, took out a patent, and made a fortune.
verb If you invent a way of doing something, you devise it. You work it out. We need to invent a new approach to the problem.
verb If you invent a story, you make it up. It is not true. He invented a weak excuse for his lateness. I think they've invented half their data.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun invention The museum has a special display of Australian inventions and discoveries.adjective inventive Flora came up with an inventive solution. He's an inventive writer.noun inventor

form.definition: noun Inverted commas are punctuation marks that you write before and after quoted words. There are different styles of inverted commas and they can be single ( ' ) or in pairs ( '' ).
form.note: ... ANOTHER TERMfor this is quotation mark.

form.definition: verb If you invest money, you put it into something such as term deposits, shares, or a small business in the hope of making a profit. He invested $20 000 in the family business.
verb If you invest time or energy in something, you spend it working at that thing. I invested many hours of work in planning for the family reunion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun investment You need to monitor your investments. Where can I get advice on investment?noun investor The small investor often gets neglected.

form.definition: verb If you investigate something, you look closely into it and try to find out what the situation is. The police are investigating the murder. I heard noises downstairs and went to investigate. They set up a committee to investigate possible solutions.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun investigation Experts are conducting an investigation into the cause of the fire.

form.definition: verb If something invigorates you, it makes you feel refreshed and energetic. I always feel invigorated after my early morning swim.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective invigorating

form.definition: adjective If something is invisible, it cannot be seen. The magic spell made him invisible. The car became invisible behind the trees. The stain's almost invisible now. The markings are invisible to the naked eye.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is visible. ... WORD FAMILYnoun invisibility

form.definition: verb If you invite someone, you ask them to do something with you as a social event. It doesn't necessarily mean that you will pay for them. How many guests have you invited to the party? Ben invited Jo to go to the pictures with him. We ought to invite them over.

verb In rather formal language, if you say you invite someone to do something, you mean you give them an opportunity to do it. You tell them they may do it. The interviewer invited me to sit down. Brad invited Donna to speak next.

verb If you say someone invites something bad to happen, you mean that they act in a way which makes it very likely. You're just inviting the boss to fire you, coming in this late every day. The filthy conditions invite disease.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun invitation I sent Jill an invitation. An open window is an invitation to burglars.

form.definition: noun An invoice is a bill for things that you have bought. It lists all the items separately with their price. They expect payment within 30 days of the invoice.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb invoice They invoiced us for $300.

form.definition: verb If something involves something else, the second thing is part of it or connected with it. The story involves three women and their relationships. Playing the piano well involves hours of practice. I couldn't face the mess involved. What does the operation involve?
verb If you involve someone in something, you cause them to take part in it. I don't want to involve you in our quarrel.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See involved.

form.definition: adjective If something is involved, it is complicated. Marie told us a long and involved story about how they'd first met. Making a job application is quite an involved process. 2a adjective If you are involved in something, you do it or take part in it. I'm involved in renovating my house at the moment. Susan has been involved in the project from the start.
adjective If you areinvolved in something, you put a lot of concentration into it. Stan's deeply involved in his work. Don't get too involveddinner's nearly ready!
adjective If you are involved with someone, you are having a romantic relationship with them. Are Dora and Ed involved?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun involvement

form.definition: noun An IOU is a written statement acknowledging a debt. I took $5 from the drawer and left an IOU.
adjective Irate is a rather formal word meaning 'angry'. He was very irate at being kept waiting.
noun The iris is the coloured part of the eye around the pupil.
verb If someone or something irks you, they annoy or irritate you. She means well, but somehow she irks me. What really irks me is the way he never clears up after himself.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective irksome It was irksome to have to start all over again.

form.definition: noun Iron is a hard, strong metal used for making things such as railings.
noun Iron is a mineral needed in the human body and found in foods such as liver and spinach.
noun Iron is an element, a pure form of the metal and the mineral.
noun An iron is an electrical appliance which you use to smooth the creases out of clothes.
noun In golf, an iron is a club with an iron head.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective iron ...an iron bar. ...the iron industry. ...the Iron Age.verb iron I've still got six shirts to iron.noun ironing The ironing was piled up on the bed.adjective ironing ...an ironing board. ...an ironing cupboard.

form.definition: noun Irony is a way of speaking where what you mean is not the same as the literal content of your words. 'What perfect weather!' she said with irony as we watched the heavy rain pouring down.

noun Irony is treating a subject in a light and slightly humorous way even though it's serious and important. The movie tackles the subject with wit and irony. She spoke of her ordeal with gentle irony.
noun Irony is a situation where things turn out in a strange and usually unfortunate way as a result of coincidence. The irony is that she missed him by only a couple of hours.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective ironic He has an ironic sense of humour. It was ironic the way it turned out.adverb ironically She spoke ironically of her experience. Ironically, he'd died the day before.

form.definition: adjective If someone is irrational, they don't behave in a calm and sensible way, but act on impulse. She's completely irrationalI wonder if she'll ever settle down.
adjective If something is irrational, it is not based on sound reasoning. It's irrational to suppose that he'll change his mind. He has an irrational fear of mice.
adjective If something is irregular, it is uneven. His pulse was irregular. There was a large irregular stain on the cloth. Be carefulthe paving's very irregular here.

adjective If events are irregular, they don't happen according to any routine and usually they don't happen very often. He lived for her irregular letters. I manage to make irregular deposits to my savings account.

adjective If a situation is irregular, it is not acceptable because it goes against the normal rules. Well, it's highly irregular, but I suppose I could let you in. This irregular state of affairs must not be allowed to continue.
adjective If a word is irregular, its inflected forms are formed in a different way to most words of the same type. We had to learn long lists of irregular verbs.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun irregularity (irregularities) The auditors discovered some serious irregularities in their accounts.adverb irregularly My front teeth are irregularly spaced. She visits only irregularly.

form.definition: adjective Something that is irrelevant is not important because it is not connected with what you are saying or dealing with. Let's not get distracted by irrelevant issues. His remarks were irrelevant to the subject.
verb If you irrigate land, you supply it with water by means of canals and pipes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun irrigation

form.definition: verb If someone or something irritates you, they annoy you or make you cross. That noise is beginning to irritate me. Stefan irritates me with his stupid jokes. It irritates me that Lara always gets first choice.
verb If something irritates a part of your body, it makes it sore or itchy. The dust irritates my nose and makes me sneeze.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun irritable I'm feeling very irritable today. He's got an irritable bowel.adjective irritating She's got a very irritating laugh.noun irritation He could barely conceal his irritation. This cream will ease the irritation.

form.definition: verb Is is the third person singular of the present tense of be.
suffix The suffix -ish is used to form adjectives, and has meanings such as 'like' or 'rather', as in childish, yellowish and lateish.
noun Islam is the religion based on the teachings of Mohammed.
noun An island is an area of land completely surrounded by water.

verb If you isolate something, you make or keep it separate or apart from other things. He had to be isolated in a sterile environment. Scientists have managed to isolate the virus. It's not easy to isolate the factors involved.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective isolated This is not an isolated incident. They live on an isolated property.

form.definition: noun An issue is an important subject about which people have different opinions. Teenage drinking is a serious issue. Let's settle the issue once and for all. What are the main issues involved? Cost isn't an issue for him.
noun An issue is also a number of a newspaper or magazine. The series continues in our next issue. There's a good article in the current issue of the 'Australian Geographic'.

verb If you issue something to someone or issue someone with something, you officially hand out something they need. On the first day we were issued with our uniforms. You can't just barge in here issuing orders.
pronoun It refers to something that has already been mentioned. The desk has stains on it. He's wrong but he won't admit it. The dog snarled as I approached it. The baby cried until I picked it up.
pronoun It can also refer to an unidentified person. Who could it be, calling at this time of night? 'Who is it?' 'It's me, Sam.'
pronoun Sometimes it refers to what you are going to say later in the sentence. It's a shame that Tony can't come. It took her five minutes to catch her breath. It was Paolo who introduced us.
pronoun It can also be used in a general way to talk about a whole situation. It doesn't matter. It's all really sad. I hate it when that happens.
pronoun It is also used as an impersonal pronoun in talking about the weather. Do you think it'll rain? It's a nice day outside.
pronoun You also use it in talking about the time or the date. 'What time is it?' 'It's nearly two.' It's Wednesday today.
noun Italian is the language spoken in Italy and in some parts of Switzerland.
adjective If someone or something comes from Italy, you describe them as Italian.
noun If something is printed in italics, the letters slope to the right. I used italics for the phrases I quoted directly.
verb If a part of your body itches, it feels unpleasant and you want to scratch it. My mosquito bites are itching like mad.
verb If you itch to do something, you are very eager and impatient to do it. I'm itching to show Cindy my new dress.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun itch I've got an itch in the middle of my back.adjective itchy The starched collar was a bit itchy.

form.definition: noun An item is one thing among a group of things. I only had five items so I went to the express lane. Several items of clothing were left behind. There are many items to discuss.
noun An item is an article in a newspaper or magazine. Did you see that item about the koalas?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb itemise (<or> itemize) The bill itemises all your long-distance calls.

form.definition: noun An itinerary is a program for a trip, listing where you are going to be each day. Often there are other details such as flight times and contact numbers. I haven't finalised my itinerary yet, but I think I'll be in Bangkok on Thursday. Have you got a copy of Mr Stewart's itinerary?
adjective Its means 'belonging to it'. The dog wagged its tail. The truck made its way up the hill.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with it's, which is a contracted form of it is.

form.definition: contraction It's is the informal or spoken form of 'it is'. It's raining. 'Who's there?' 'It's Bob.'
contraction It's is also the informal or spoken form of 'it has'. It's been nice to see you. It's been years since we saw him.

pronoun Itself is the reflexive form of it. You use it when the thing following a verb or preposition is the same as the subject of the sentence. The cat was washing itself. The path doubled back on itself.
pronoun Itself is an emphatic form of it. The house itself was undamaged, but part of the garage burned down. This is not a problem in itself, but it may lead to difficulties.
contraction I've is the informal or spoken form of 'I have'. I've lost my keys. I've never been there.
noun Ivy is a plant that grows up walls and fences. It has small leaves with pointed edges.[fa[xp
